body.p: Dashboard users see the tabs that they need to perform their roles' tasks.

section.title: Cloud Tab Tasks
section.p: Concepts:
The Cloud tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to access information on a cloud-wide basis.
For example, on Cloud > Projects, you can see a list of all projects in the cloud. You can edit, create, or delete projects on the Cloud > Projects window.

section.title: How to See All Services
section.p: The Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of services that are registered in the cloud. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To see cloud services:

ol.li:
Click Cloud > Services. The following cloud services display.
Service Name Service Type Description
Eve Provisioning A composite provisioning service that uses a topology design and profile to create VMs, volumes, and network segments as described in the topology. Eve uses the Graffiti service for determining resource pool existence, traits, and user identity mapping.
Focus Design storage Repository for topology designs and profiles that are used for provisioning.
Glance Image storage Repository for images used to create new VMs.
Graffiti Registry A searchable directory to find cloud resources based on their capabilities. An example of a cloud resource is resource pool definitions that you can use to provision to various cloud providers.
Keystone Identity and security Provides user authentication and tracks various projects within the regions. If Keystone is disabled, you cannot log into the Administration Dashboard.
Quantum (new name — Neutron) Networking Provides network management for VMs.

For each service, you see the following information:
Service URL: This column shows the IP address where the service is running.
Status: Whether enabled.
Actions: If a service supports Rest APIs, you see Rest API under the Actions column.

section.title: How to Use the REST API Action
section.p: The HP Cloud OS API Documentation application is a tool for describing, producing, and visualizing RESTful web services. Its purpose is to enable client and documentation systems to update at the same pace as the server. The documentation of methods, parameters, and models are tightly integrated into the service code, allowing APIs to stay in sync.
If a service supports the HP Cloud OS API Documentation application, you see REST API under the Actions column.
Click REST API to start the documentation application for a service.
For information about how to use the documentation application, see the Develop topic.

section.title: How to See All Domains
section.p: The Domains window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of domains in the cloud. (Currently, the cloud contains one domain.) To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To view all domains in the cloud:

li.p: Click Cloud > Domains.
Information shown includes domain name and description.
Optional: To see details of a domain, click the Domain Name.
Information shown includes domain name, ID, description, whether the domain is enabled, and a link to the domain.

section.title: How to Access All Projects
section.p: The Project window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all projects in the cloud and to work with those projects. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

Projects are groupings that allow designated users to view the same set of content. Projects protect topology designs and profiles, and realized resources (such as VMs, volumes, and others) from being visible to all users.
To see a list of all projects:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window. Projects are listed alphabetically by Name.
Information shown includes project name and description.
Optional: To display project details, click Project Name to open the Overview window.
Information shown includes project name, ID, description, whether enabled, users and roles.

section.title: How to Create a Project
section.p: When you create a project, you need only one required entry - Name. You can keep default settings for integrations and limits, and add users later.
To create a project:

ol.li: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.
Click Create Project to open the Create Project dialog box.

On the Project Info tab, enter:
Name: required.
Description: optional.
Enabled: By default, Enabled is selected, which means project content is available to assigned users.

Optional: On the Project Members tab, add project members from the list of available users. Click the plus sign (+) to add a project member. Click the minus sign (-) to remove a member.
Note: You do not see cloud administrators under Available Users, because they are automatically added to projects.

Optional: On the Integrations tab, select Create Default Resource Pool if you need to create a resource pool for your compute regions. You select this option if your HP Cloud OS Operational Dashboard administrator used the advanced method to create compute regions. The advanced option does not automatically create resource pools. In most cases, you can leave the default (not selected) for Create Default Resource Pool. Operational Dashboard administrators usually create compute regions that automatically contain a resource pool.
Note: You can create a resource pool later. See How to Create a Resource Pool.

Optional: On the Compute Limits tab, select a Region for the project. Accept or edit the Absolute Computer Limits. This sets limits on how many system resources (such as CPU cores, floating IP, and others) project users can consume at one time in that region.

Optional: On the Storage Limits tab, accept or edit the Absolute Computer Limits. This sets limits on how many storage resources (such as snapshots, volumes, and others) project users can consume at one time.
Click Create Project.

section.title: How to See a Project's Usage
section.p: To see a project's usage:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.
Find the project where you want to see usage, and click More > View Usage to open the Usage Summary window.
You can select a different month to view and click Submit.
Download CSV Summary opens a text file in Microsoft Excel with current month usage information.

section.title: How to Add or Remove a Project User
section.p: Before adding a new user to a project, make sure the user is logged out. If you add users to a project while they are logged in, the Administration Dashboard may log them out without warning or show an error message. If so, users should sign out and sign back in. Carefully coordinate with users, or schedule adding users to a project when they are not logged in.
To add or remove a project user:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.
Find the project, and click Modify Users to open the Edit Project dialog box at the Project Members tab.
Use the plus sign (+) to add Available Users. Use the minus sign (-) to remove Project Members.

Note: You can only add or remove project users and project administrators. Higher level roles, such as cloud administrators and Arch are added automatically. To see all project users, open the detail view of the project. See How to Access All Projects.
Click Save.

section.title: How to Change a Project's Compute or Storage Limits
section.p: You can change your default compute and storage limits to more closely reflect your capacity. For example, if your compute region is hosted on a very large system, you can offer users more than the default capacity. If your compute region is hosted on a VM, you can restrict capacity.
To change a project's compute limits:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.

Find the project where you want to change the compute limits, and click
More > Modify Compute Limits
to open the Edit Project dialog box.
On the Compute Limits tab of the dialog box, select a Region. Compute limits are defined on a region-by-region basis.
Keep or modify the existing Absolute Compute Limits. Enter integer values that are -1 (to set unlimited capacity) or greater.
Click Save.

section.p: To change a project's storage limits:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.

Find the project where you want to change the storage limits, and click
More > Modify Storage Limits
to open the Edit Project dialog box.
On the Storage Limits tab of the dialog box, keep or modify the existing Absolute Storage Limits.
Click Save.

section.title: How to Edit a Project Name or Description
section.p: To edit a project:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.
Find the project to edit, and click More > Edit Project to open the Edit Project dialog box.
On the Project Info tab, you can change the Name, Description, and whether the project is Enabled.
Click Save.

section.title: How to Delete or Restore a Project
section.p: When you delete a project, it is marked for deletion by adding a tilde (~) prefix to its name.

The project is not actually deleted until a cloud clean-up utility runs. At that time, all resources associated with the project are removed. You can restore the project any time before the utility runs.
To delete a project:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects view.
Find the project you want to delete, and click More > Delete Project.
In the confirmation dialog, click Delete Project. The project list redisplays. The project appears at the bottom of the list and is marked for deletion.

section.p: To restore a project:

li.p: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects view.
Find the project to restore. It display at the bottom of the Project Name list with a tilde (~) preceding the name.
Click More > Restore Project.
In the confirmation dialog, verify your selection and then click Restore. The project is restored.

section.title: How to Access All Users
section.p: The Users window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all users in the cloud and to work with those users. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

Users include both people and services (such as Nova). When you create a person user, you must add that user to a project and assign a project role. Later, you can add the user to additional projects and roles.
To see a list of users:

li.p: Click Cloud > Users to open the Users window. Information shown includes user name, role, email address, and whether the user is enabled.
Optional: Click an email address to automatically create an email addressed to that user.
Optional: To see user details, click User Name to open an Overview window. Information shown includes all the information from the Users window, and every project and role associated with the user.

section.title: How to Create a User
section.p: To create a user:

ol.li: Click Cloud > Users to open the Users window.
Click Create User to open the Create User dialog box.

On the User tab of the dialog box, enter the User Name and Password.
Optional: Enter an Email address for the user.

Click the Project tab to assign the user to a project.
Select a Primary Project for the user.
Select a project role from the list. The user will be assigned that role on the project.
Optional: Click the Cloud tab if you want to assign the user cloud-specific roles. See Administration Dashboard Tasks by Roles.
Click Create User.

section.title: How to Edit a User
section.p: Note: You cannot edit control users such as Trash or Nova. Edit does not display for users that cannot be edited.
To edit a user:

li.p: Click Cloud > Users to open the Users window.
Find the user you want to edit, and click Edit to open the Update User dialog box.
On the User tab of the dialog box, update the User Name, Email, or Password.
On the Cloud tab, update the user cloud role. See Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
Click Update User.

section.title: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a User
section.p: Note: You cannot delete, disable, or enable the following users: Admin, Arch, and control users such as Trash or Nova. Delete, Disable, and Enable do not display for those users.
Deleting a user marks the user for deletion by adding a tilde () prefix to the name. The user will be permanently removed from this list when a cloud clean-up utility runs.
To delete a user:

li.p: Click Cloud > Users to open the Users window.
Find the user you want to delete. Click More > Delete User.
A confirmation dialog box opens, warning you that the action cannot be undone. To confirm, click Delete User.
The Users list redisplays and the user is marked for deletion. The deleted user will be permanently removed from the list when the cloud clean-up utility runs.

section.p: A deleted user is not removed from the Administration Dashboard until the cloud clean-up utility runs. You can restore a deleted user before the utility runs.
To restore a deleted user:

li.p: Click Cloud > Users to open the Users window.
Find the user you want to restore and click Restore User.
A confirmation dialog box opens. To confirm, click Restore.
The Users list redisplays and the user moves back into the list alphabetically.

section.p: Note: After you restore a user, the user is no longer associated with any project.
You can disable a user, so the user remains in the Administration Dashboard, but cannot log in.
To disable a user:

li.p: Click Cloud > Users to open the User view.
Find the user you want to disable. Click More > Disable User.
The user remains on the list but the Enabled field changes to False.

section.p: You can enable a disabled user. To enable a user:

li.p: Click Users to open the User view.
Find the user you want to enable. Click More > Enable User.
The user remains on the list and the Enabled field changes to True.

section.title: How to Access All Roles
section.p: The Roles window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all roles in the cloud and to work with those roles. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
Use roles to give a user privileges to access project resources. Different roles assign different privileges.
To see all roles:

li.p: Click Cloud > Roles to open the Roles window. Roles display alphabetically by Role Name.
Optional: To see role details, click the Role Name to open an Overview window.
Information shown includes role name, ID, and all users and projects associated with the role.

section.title: How to Create a Role
section.p: To create a role:

li.p: Click Cloud > Roles to open the Roles view.
Click Create Role.
On the Create Role dialog box, enter a Role Name and click Create Role.
The role is added to the Roles list alphabetically.

section.title: How to Edit a Role
section.p: Users with permission can edit a role to change the name that is associated with the role. The role maintains the privileges that were previously assigned to it, but with a different name.
In a common use case, you edit a role name to be more appropriate to your company's titles.
Note: You cannot edit the Admin or Arch roles.
To edit a role:

li.p: Click Cloud > Roles to open the Roles window.
Find the role you want to edit and click Edit.
On the Update Role dialog box, edit the Role Name and click Update Role.

section.title: How to Delete a Role
section.p: When you delete a role, it is removed throughout the Administration Dashboard.
Note: You cannot delete the Admin or Arch roles.
To delete a role:

li.p: Click Cloud > Roles to open the Roles view.
Find the role to delete, and click More > Delete Role.
In the confirmation dialog, verify your selection and click Delete Role.

section.title: How to Access All Images
section.p: The Images window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all images in the cloud and to work with those images. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Roles.
If you create a Public image, project users can access the image and use it to launch a VM. Only Public images are visible to all users.
The Images window shows all non-snapshot images with the following formats:

row.entry: AMI (Amazon Machine Image) — Not valid unless it is associated with a kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI).

section.p: To see a list of images:

li.p: Click Cloud > Images to open the Images window.
Information shown includes image name, type, status, format, whether the image is public, and whether the image is protected.
Optional: To see image details, click the Image Name to open the Image Overview window.

section.title: How to Create an Image
section.p: The image must be available on an HTTP URL. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.
To create an image:

li.p: Click Cloud > Images to open the Images window.
Click Create Image to open the Create an Image dialog box.
Enter Name and optional Description.
Select an Image Source.

ul.li: Image Location to enter and external URL from which to load the image.
Image File to browse to a local image.

li.p: Enter an Image Location that meets the following requirements:
a. A valid and direct HTTP URL to the image binary. URLs that redirect or serve error pages will result in unusable images.
Note: If you do not have rights to the image binary url, you receive an error when trying to create the image
b. The image must be accessible to the Image Service.
c. The image must be in a supported format.
Note: If you upload an image with a format that is not supported, you will receive an Error 404, Not Found error when you attempt to create the image.
Select a Format from the menu. The image must be in one of the formats listed.
Enter the Minimum Disk space and Minimum Ram.
Select Public if you want the image visible to all users in the cloud. Your user role must have the appropriate permission to make an image Public.
Select Protected to mark the image as read-only. The image cannot be edited or deleted.

Click Create Image. If successful, the image displays with an Active status. If creation is not successful within a specified amount of time (set by your system administrator; typically no more than five minutes), the Status of the image in the list displays Upload Failed.

section.p: Note: Only AMI, RAW, and QCOW2 images are launchable.

section.title: How to Launch an Image
section.p: You can only launch images that are formatted as AMI, RAW, and QCOW2. Launching an image provisions it to the cloud.
To launch an image:

ol.li: Click Cloud > Images to open the Images view.
Find the image to launch and then click Launch to open the Launch Instance dialog box. The dialog opens to the Details tab. Some fields are automatically populated from the image.

Enter or edit the Details tab information as needed:
Instance Source: Specify whether you are using an image or snapshot.
Image: Select from the list of images that have been uploaded to the system.
Instance Name: The name of the host you are creating (Required). Note: At this point, you can go ahead and launch the instance, using the defaults for the remaining options.
Flavor: Indicates the size of the node. When you select a flavor here, the Flavor Details table on the right changes to show the node properties and values associated with your size selection.
Instance Count: Can be more than 1.

Use the Access and Security tab to control access to your instance via keypairs and security groups.
Keypair: Keypairs are SSH security keys that are 512 bits long, provide authentication, and allow you to exchange traffic securely within a VM. These credentials are injected into images when they are launched.
Creating a new keypair registers the public key and downloads the private key (a .pem file), allowing you to log into the VM. The public key gets installed on the VM; the private key is used to log in.
To add a keypair, either:
Select a keypair from the list, or
Click (+) to import a keypair. Enter Keypair Name and Public Key
Admin Pass and Confirm Admin Pass
Security Groups
Use the Networking tab to select one or more networks. You can click the plus (+) symbol or drag and drop to make your selections. Use the minus (-) symbol to remove networks.
Use the Volume Options tab to select boot options for an instance that launches with attached storage.
Use the Post Creation tab to customize the instance by adding a script to run after launch. The Customization Script field is analogous to "User Data" in other systems.
Click Launch. If successful, the image is added to the Images list with an Active status.

section.title: How to Edit an Image
section.p: You cannot modify an image format.

When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.
To edit an image:

li.p: Click Cloud > Images to open the Images window.
Find the image you want to edit, and click More > Edit.
Keep or edit:

ul.li: Name : As desired.
Description: Optional.
Architecture: Optional information about hardware requirements for the VM the image runs on. For example, x86 64 bits.
Format: You cannot edit format. Note: If you edit an AMI image, you can select a different AKI and ARI.
Public: Visibility.
Protected: Select to mark the image as read-only. A protected image cannot be edited or deleted.

li.p: Click Update Image.

section.title: How to Delete an Image
section.p: If you have permission to delete a protected image, you must first edit the image, so it is not protected. See How to Edit an Image.

After you delete an image, you cannot create instances based on that (deleted) image. Also, if you delete an image that a topology document references, the infrastructure design document will fail during an attempt to provision.
To delete one or more images:

li.p: Click Cloud > Images to open the Images window.
To delete one image, click More > Delete Image.
Optional: To delete one or more images, select the images and click Delete Images.
A confirmation dialog box opens, warning that the action cannot be undone.
Click Delete Image. The Images list redisplays and the image or images are removed.

section.title: Region Tab Tasks
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to work with region services and content. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

A Region is a compute grouping that provides the context for the usage of compute servers, networking systems, and storage resources. A region makes use of a defined set of users, projects, topology templates, profiles, and services governed by a single OpenStack(R) Keystone domain service. Regions are used to group different locations, different types of hardware, or to separate different resources belonging to different groups.
If your cloud contains more than one region, select the region to manage:
On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Note: Changing regions might switch the point of action to the Project tab. Click the Region tab again to display the selected region.

How to Access Flavors and Flavor Extra Specs

section.title: How to See an Overview of Usage
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a usage summary.
To see an overview of usage:

li.p: Click Region > Overview to see limits and usage for the current month.
You can select a different month to view and click Submit.
Download CSV Summary opens a text file in Microsoft Excel with current month usage information.

section.title: How to See Instances
section.p: Instances are running VMs. The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see region instances. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To see a list of instances:

li.p: Click Region > Instances to open the Instances window.
Information shown includes instance name, image name, IP address, size, keypair, status, task, power state, and uptime.
Optional: To display details of a region instance, click the Name to open a window that offers the following tabs:

ul.li: Overview, where you see instance details and specifications.
Log, which is the system log from the VM. Use this log for debugging and troubleshooting. You can view the full instance log or specify the number of lines of the log file to view.
Console, where you can remotely log directly in to the VM.

li.xref: How to See the Instance Console, Console Log, and Overview

section.title: How to See the Instance Console, Console Log, and Overview
section.p: The instance console is the system log from the VM, and it is used for debugging and troubleshooting. You can view the full instance log or specify the number of lines of the log file to view.
To display the instance console:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Instances to open the Instances window.
Find the instance you want to learn more about, and click More > Console to open the Console window.

Optional: Click the Log tab to see the most recent 35 lines from the Instance Console Log. To change the number of display lines, enter a value in Log Length and click Go. Click View Full Log to view all logged entries in a separate window.
Optional: Click the Overview tab to see high level information (such as status, specs, security, and so on) about the region instance.

section.title: How to Edit an Instance
section.p: To edit a region instance:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click to open the Instances window.
Find the Instance you want to edit, and click Edit Instance.
Select the Info tab to update the Name.
Select the Security Groups tab to edit security groups. Use the plus symbol (+) to add groups and the minus symbol (-) to remove groups.

ul.li: All Security Groups — A list of security groups that are associated with the project, but not the instance.
Instance Security Groups — A list of security groups that are currently associated with the instance.

li.p: Click Save.

section.title: How to Suspend, Resume, or Terminate an Instance
section.p: When you terminate an instance, the Administration Dashboard shuts the VM down, and the resources associated with it are released. You cannot start the VM after it is terminated, because it no longer exists. Termination is scheduled, because it takes some time to free all the resources. The scheduled termination script runs in the background.
When you terminate an instance:

li.p: Any changes associated with the volume that the image is running on are discarded.
Any changes associated with the volume implied by the disk space (ephemeral) that are specified in the flavor are discarded.
Any changes associated with attached volumes are retained in the attached volume and could be reattached to a different VM.
The VM is removed from any security group it was associated with, and frees its floating IP addresses.

section.p: To terminate one or more instances:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Instances to open the Instances window.
To terminate one instance, find the instance and select More > Terminate Instance.
Optional: To terminate multiple instances, select the instances you want to terminate, and click Terminate Instances.
In the warning dialog box, verify your selection and click Terminate Instance(s).

section.title: How to See Info about Services, Compute Services, and Default Quotas
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see information about services, compute service and default quotas (limits). To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

p.xref: How to See a List of Services
How to See a List of Compute Services
How to See a List of Default Quotas (Limits)

section.title: How to See a List of Services
section.p: The Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of registered services.
Services can be run on the same node as the compute region controller or they can be run on a different server.
To see a list of services, click Region > Info > Services tab, which opens the Services window.

row.entry: A region is constructed by installing and naming a compute server called Nova.
Repository for topology designs and profiles that are used for provisioning.
Repository for images used to create new VMs.
Provides block-storage based volume management for VMs.
An alternate service interface for the Nova service.

A composite provisioning service that uses a topology design and profile to create VMs, volumes, and network segments as described in the topology. Eve uses the Graffiti service for determining resource pool existence, traits, and user identity mapping.
Provides user authentication and tracks various projects within the regions. If Keystone is disabled, you cannot log into the Administration Dashboard.
A searchable directory to find cloud resources based on their capabilities. An example of a cloud resource is resource pool definitions that you can use to provision to various cloud providers.

section.p: The Host column shows the IP address where the service is running.
The Status shows whether the service is enabled.

section.title: How to See a List of Compute Services
section.p: The Compute Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of registered compute services.
To see a list of registered compute services, click Region > Info > Compute Services tab, which opens the Compute Services window.

section.title: How to See a List of Default Quotas (Limits)
section.p: The Default Quotas window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of region quotas. The Administration Dashboard provides default limits, but you can modify those limits at the project level. See How to Change a Project's Compute or Storage Limits.
To see a list of region default quotas (limits), click Region > Info > Default Quotas tab, which opens the Default Quotas window.

section.title: How to Access Volumes
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission see volumes. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

Volumes are the disk storage volumes that have been created in the region. Volumes are persistent, meaning you can create data in these volumes and attach to various VMs (instances) over time as needed.
To see a list of volumes:

li.p: Click Region > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
The information shown includes volume name, host size, status, type, attached to, and the associated project name.
Optional: To see details of a volume, click the Name to open an Overview window.
Information shown includes volume name, ID, status, specs, and attachments.

p.xref: How to Create a Volume Type
How to Delete a Volume Type

section.title: How to Create a Volume Type
section.p: To create a region volume type:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Volumes to open the Volumes window.
Click Create Volume Type.
Enter a Name. This is commonly associated with the storage backend driver capabilities, such as Performance, SSD, or Backup.
Click Create Volume Type.

section.title: How to Delete a Volume Type
section.p: To delete one or more volume types:

li.p: Click Region > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
Find the volume type you want to delete, and click Delete Volume Type.
Optional: To delete more than one volume type, select the volume types and click Delete Volume Types.
In the confirmation dialog, verify your selection and then click Delete Volume Types.

section.title: How to Delete a Volume
section.p: Deleting a volume means the volume will no longer exist, the data will be lost, it cannot be attached to any VM, and no user can access it. Deleting a volume cannot be undone.
To delete one or more volumes:

li.p: Click Region > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
Find the volume you want to delete and click Delete Volume.
Optional: To delete more than one volume, select the volumes and click Delete Volumes.
In the confirmation dialog, verify your selection and then click Delete Volume.

section.title: How to Access Images
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of images (that are not snapshots) and to work with those images. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
Images are stored at the Domain level with a single Glance service and are unaffected by region selection. Only Public images are visible to all users.
Launchable images must be in one of the following formats:

row.entry: AMI (Amazon Machine Image) — Not valid unless it is associated with a kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI).

section.p: To see a list of all images:

li.p: Click Regions > Images to open the Images window.
The information shown includes name, type, status, whether the image is public or protected, and format.
Optional: To see image details, click the Image Name link to open its Overview window.
The information shown includes image name, ID, whether protected, checksum, creation date, updated date, and specs.

section.title: How to Create an Image
section.p: You can create and configure an image to upload to the image service used by the Administration Dashboard. The image must be available on an HTTP URL. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.
To create an image:

li.p: Click Region > Images > Create Image.
In the Create an Image dialog box, enter a Name.
Enter an Image Location that meets the following requirements:
a. A valid and direct HTTP URL to the image binary. URLs that redirect or serve error pages will result in unusable images.
Note: If you do not have rights to the image binary url, you receive an error when trying to create the image
b. The image must be accessible to the image service.
c. The image must be in a supported format.
Note: If you upload an image with a format that is not supported, you will receive an Error 404, Not Found error when you attempt to create the image.
Select an Image File.
Select a Format from the drop-down list. The image must be in one of the formats listed.
Enter the Minimum Disk space and Minimum Ram.
Keep Public checked if you want the image visible to all users.

Click Create Image. If successful, the image displays with an Active status. If creation is not successful within a specified amount of time (set by your system administrator; typically no more than five minutes), the Status of the image in the list displays Upload Failed.

section.p: Note: Only AMI, RAW, and QCOW2 images are launchable.

section.title: How to Edit an Image
section.p: You cannot modify an image format.

When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.
To edit an image:

li.p: Click Region > Images to open the Images window.
Find the image to edit. Click Edit.
Keep or edit:

ul.li: Name: As desired.
Description: Optional description.
Architecture: Optional information about hardware requirements for the VM the image runs on. For example, x86 64 bits.
Public: Visibility

li.p: Note: If you edit an AMI image, you can select a different AKI and ARI.

ul.li: Protected: Select to create a read-only image. Protected images cannot be edited or deleted.

ol.li: Click Update Image.

section.title: How to Delete an Image
section.p: After you delete an image, you cannot create instances based on that (deleted) image. Also, if you delete an image that a topology template references, provisioning will fail.
Images are protected from deletion by rules. If you are not allowed to delete an image, you do not see Delete Image.
To delete one or more images:

li.p: Click Region > Images to open the Images window.
Find the image you want to delete, and click Delete Image.
Optional: To delete more than one image, select the images and click Delete Images.
A confirmation dialog box opens, warning that the action cannot be undone.
Click Delete Image. The Images list redisplays and the image or images are removed.

section.title: How to Access Networks
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of networks and work with those networks. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To see a list of networks:

li.p: Click Region > Networks.
The information shown includes the networks' status, administrative state, associated subnets, and whether the network is shared.
Optional: To see the details of a network, click the Network Name. The Administration Dashboard opens the Network Overview window of the associated project.

p.xref: How to Create an External Network
How to Create a Private Network

section.title: How to Create an External Network
section.p: The cloud can only support one external network, so the network should be created as a shared network. As a shared network, it can be used by multiple projects, if needed.
To create an external network:

ol.li: Click Region > Networks to open the Networks window.

Click Create Network to open the Create Network dialog box where you:
Enter a Name for the network.
Select a Project to associate with the network.
Keep Admin State selected to create a network that is active and operational.
Select Shared to associate the network with all projects in the cloud.
Select External Network to create a network that is operational outside the cloud.
Note: If you select Admin State and Shared, and do not select External Network, the combination of settings is invalid. You can create the network, but it will fail during provisioning.
Click Create Network.
If the network is created successfully, the Administration Dashboard displays the network information on the Project > Infrastructure > Networks window.

section.title: How to Create a Private Network
section.p: To create a private network:

ol.li: Click Region > Networks to open the Networks window.

Click Create Networks and to open the Create Network dialog box where you:
Enter a Name for the network.
Select a Project to associate with the network.
Keep Admin State selected to create a network that is active and operational.
Do not select Shared, because you are creating a private network. You do not want to share the network with other projects.
Do not select External Network. External networks are always shared.
Note: If you select Admin State and Shared, and do not select External Network, the combination of settings is invalid. You can create the network, but it will fail during provisioning.
Click Create Network.
If the network is created successfully, the Administration Dashboard displays the network information on the Project > Infrastructure > Networks window.

section.title: How to Edit a Network
section.p: The Region > Networks window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see all the networks in all the regions, so administrators can decide which networks to edit.
If you originally created the network for a single project, and you later decide to share it, you must edit the Shared and External Network options.
To edit a network:

li.p: Click Region > Networks to open the Networks window.
Find the network you want to edit, and click Edit Networks to open the Edit Network dialog box.
Keep or edit the Name, Admin State, Shared, or External Network values. You cannot edit the ID.
Note: If you select Admin State and Shared, and do not select External Network, the combination of settings is invalid. You can create the network, but it will fail during provisioning.
Click Save Changes.

section.title: How to Delete a Network
section.p: The Region > Networks window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see all the networks in all the regions, so users can decide which networks to delete.

A network is referenced by subnets and routers, which are, in turn, referenced by VMs. You cannot delete a network that has VMs connected to one of its subnets. To delete a network, VMs must not be connected to that network.
To delete one or more networks:

li.p: Click Region > Networks to open the Networks window.
To delete one network, click More > Delete Network.
Optional: To delete one or more networks, select the networks and click Delete Networks.
In the Confirm Delete Network dialog, verify your selection, and click Delete Network(s).
The Networks window opens, and you do not see the networks listed.

section.title: How to Access Routers
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of routers and work with those routers. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To see a list of routers:

li.p: Click Region > Routers to open the Routers window.
The information shown includes the router name, status, external network, and associated project.
Optional: To see the details of a router, click the Name. The Administration Dashboard opens the Routers window in the associated project. You are now working on the project level.

section.title: How to Delete a Router
section.p: The Region > Routers window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see all the routers in all the regions, so users can decide which routers to delete.
To delete one or more routers:

li.p: Click Region > Routers to open the Routers window.
Select one or more routers, and then click Delete Routers.
In the confirmation dialog, verify your selection, and then click Delete Router.
The Routers window opens, and you do not see the routers listed.

section.title: How to Access Flavors and Flavor Extra Specs
section.p: The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of flavors and work with those flavors. To learn whether you have permission, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

Flavors are machine configurations that can be used to create new VMs. A flavor describes the amount of memory, number of CPUs, and ephemeral disk space available to the VM. You can create an extra spec key-value for a flavor.
To see a list of flavors, click Regions > Flavors to open the Flavors window. The information shown includes name, VCPUs, RAM, Root Disk, ephemeral disk, swap disk, and ID.

p.xref: How to Create a Flavor Extra Spec
How to Edit a Flavor Extra Spec
How to Delete a Flavor Extra Spec

section.title: How to Create a Flavor
section.p: Only cloud architects can create flavors. Creating a flavor defines a new configuration used to create new VMs. Typically, the pre-defined flavors m1.tiny through m1.xlarge are valid.
To create a flavor:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Click Create Flavor to open the Create Flavor dialog box.
All fields are required. All fields are integer values except for the Name field.
Click Create Flavor. The list redisplays with the new flavor listed alphabetically and a system-assigned Flavor ID.

section.title: How to Edit a Flavor
section.p: To edit a region flavor:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Find the flavor you want to edit, and click Edit Flavor to open the Edit Flavor dialog box.
Keep or change the values.
Click Save.

section.title: How to Delete a Flavor
section.p: When you delete a flavor, the flavor is no longer visible in the Administration Dashboard and cannot be used to create a new VM, to assign in resource pool services, or to specify in Topology Designs.

A deleted flavor still exists in the Nova database until the clean flavors script (scheduled by a system administrator) runs. The script cannot delete a flavor, if the flavor is in use by an active instance. You must terminate the instance.
Note: If all flavors are deleted, you cannot create VMs.
To delete one or more flavors:

li.p: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.
Click Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Select the flavors you want to delete. To select all, click the top checkbox in the header row.
Click Delete Flavors.
In the Confirm Delete Flavors dialog box, verify your selections and then click Delete Flavors.
Wait for the success message.

section.title: How to Create a Flavor Extra Spec
section.p: You can create an extra spec key-value for a flavor.
To create an extra spec for a flavor:

li.p: Click Region > Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Find the flavor in the Flavors list, and click More > View Extra Specs to open the Extra Specs window.
Click Create to open the Create Flavor Extra Spec dialog box. Enter:
Click Create.

section.title: How to Edit a Flavor Extra Spec
section.p: You can edit an extra spec value. If you make changes to the extra spec name, the Administration Dashboard creates a new extra specs key.
To edit a flavor extra spec:

li.p: Click Region > Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Find the flavor where you want to edit specs, and click More > View Extra Specs to open the Extra Specs window.
Click Edit.
Make changes to Value and then click Save.

section.title: How to Delete a Flavor Extra Spec
section.p: To delete a flavor extra specs key:

li.p: Click Region > Flavors to open the Flavors window.
Find the flavor where you want to delete specs. Click More > View Extra Specs to open the Extra Specs window.
Find the extra spec you want to delete. Click More > Delete Extra Spec. A confirmation window opens, warning you that the action cannot be undone.
Click Delete Extra Spec. The extra spec is deleted from the Extra Specs list and the system.

section.title: Project Tab Tasks
section.p: Projects are groupings that allow designated users to view the same set of content. Projects protect topology templates, infrastructure designs, and realized resources (such as VMs, volumes, and others) from being visible to all users.
To learn about which tasks you can perform on the Project tab, see your role under Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

p.xref: How to See a Project Overview
How to See a Network Topology Diagram
How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair
How to Access Your Authentication Token

section.title: How to See a Project Overview
section.p: To see a project overview:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Overview > Overview to see limit and usage summaries for the current month.
Optional: Change the From and To range, and click Submit to see limit and usage summaries for a different time period.
Optional: Click Download CSV Summary to open a text file in Microsoft Excel with current month usage information.

section.title: Running Topologies
section.p: To see a list of running topologies:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Running Topologies to open the Running Topologies window.
Information shown includes topology name, action, state, task, and last update.
Optional: To see details of a running topology, click the Topology Name, to open a window that offers the following tabs:

p.xref: How to Delete or Terminate a Running Topology

section.title: How to Launch a Topology
section.p: You can launch the latest version of a topology design.
To launch a topology design:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Running Topologies to open the Topologies window.
Click Launch Topology.
Select a deployment profile. (Required).
Enter a meaningful Infrastructure Name (Required).
Click Launch Topology.
Wait for the success message.
Verify that the topology you just created is included in the Running Topologies list.

section.p: Servers that are part of the topology will appear in the Instances list, but the whole topology will be in the Running Topologies list.

section.title: How to Delete or Terminate a Running Topology
section.p: When you delete a running topology, the Administration Dashboard stops the VM and other topology elements (such as networks, volumes, and others), and permanently removes them. This action cannot be undone.
To delete a running topology:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Running Topologies to open the Topologies window.
Select the topology you want to delete and then click Delete Topology.
Wait for the success message.
Verify that the deleted topology is excluded from the Topologies list.

section.p: Note: Although terminated topologies are not running, they are still included in the Running Topologies window, with an updated State.
To terminate a running topology:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Running Topologies to open the Topologies window.
Select the Topology you want to terminate, and click Terminate Topology. The State changes to Inactive.

section.p: Terminating a topology can fail in the following case:

li.p: Assume that you provision topology A, and it includes a subnet, router and security group.
Assume that you next provision topology B, and it uses the subnet, router, and security group from topology A.

section.p: If you attempt to terminate topology A, the terminate will fail for all components that are also provisioned to topology B. You must terminate topology B before you can terminate topology A.

section.title: Deployment Profiles
section.p: To see a list of deployment profiles:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Deployment Profiles to open the Deployments window.
Information shown includes deployment name, version, based on, scope, and associated project.
Optional: To see details of a deployment profile, click the Deployment Name to open a window that offers the following tabs:

ul.li: Overview, where you see detailed deployment profile information, including versions.
Contents, where you see deployment profile contents.

li.xref: How to Launch a Deployment Profile

section.title: How to Launch a Deployment Profile
section.p: To launch a deployment profile:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Deployment Profiles to open the Deployment Profiles window.
Find the deployment that you want to launch. Click Launch to open the Launch dialog box where you:
a. Accept or modify the Infrastructure Name.
b. Click Launch.
If the launch is successful, you create a running topology. A deployment profile can be launched multiple times to create multiple running topologies. See Running Topologies.

section.title: Resource Pools
section.p: Resource pools are used to access various cloud providers. For multiple regions, one resource pool is required for each region.
A resource pool consists of resources in a single cloud. A resource pool could represent one compute region, or it could represent a pool of resources on another cloud provider.
Resource pools help you locate compute and storage resources to use when you provision.
Depending upon how your cloud was created, your cloud might automatically contain a default resource pool.

Graffiti is the service used for resource pool registry. Every time you want to access a different cloud provider, you must define a new record in the Graffiti Resource Pool Registry. These records define how to access a certain cloud provider.
To see a list of resource pools:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window.
Information shown includes resource pool name, type, version, scope, user name and provider.
Optional: To see resource pool details, click the Resource Pool Name to open an Overview window.
Information shown includes resource pool name, type, scope, ID information, provider information, and more.

p.xref: How to Create a Resource Pool
How to Edit a Resource Pool
How to Add, Edit, or Delete a Resource Pool Service
How to Delete a Resource Pool

section.title: How to Create a Resource Pool
section.p: Resource pools help you locate compute and storage resources to use when you provision.
Depending upon how your cloud was created, your cloud might automatically contain default resource pools for the cloud's compute regions.
To create a resource pool:

ol.li: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window. If resource pools have been created, you see them listed on the window.
Click Create Resource Pool to open the Create Resource Pool dialog box.

Select a Cloud Type to create a resource pool when you are using local (on premise services) or HP Cloud services.
Custom: All provider details are required.
HP Cloud OS - OpenStack(R) (Grizzly): The dashboard provides values for the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard environment. Provider details are not required.
HP Cloud - OpenStack(R) (Diablo): The dashboard provides values for the HP Cloud Services environment. You must enter Provider Details, which are required.
Custom - OpenStack(R) (Grizzly): Provides maximum flexibility when you are creating a resource pool. Details and Provider Details are required.

Select a Compute Region to create a resource pool when you are using local (on premise) services or HP Cloud services. If you do not select a Compute Region, you must enter information in the remaining fields.

In the Details section:
Enter a Name.
Select a Scope:
Private, cloud: Allows you access while working in any project. This resource pool can only be viewed by the user who created it, from any project of which the user is a member, and by cloud administrators.
Private, project: Allows you access while working in the current project. This resource pool can only be viewed by the user who created it in the project in which it was created, and by cloud administrators.
Public, cloud: Allows access for all users. This resource pool can be viewed by anyone in the cloud, in any project.
Public, project: Allows you and other project members access. This resource pool can be viewed by members of the project in the project in which it was created, and by cloud administrators.

Select a Cloud Profile to represent the current supported OpenStack(R) version and capabilities of the cloud to which you are deploying.
HP Cloud OS Grizzly
HP Cloud Service
Note: The dashboard automatically enters Type, Version, Region ID and Provider URL based upon the cloud type and compute region you selected.

Optional: In the Provider Details section, enter a Project ID, User Domain Name, Project Domain Name, User Name, and Password. Enter the password again in Confirm Password to validate.
If you are using a local (on premise service), such as HP Cloud OS, you do not need an account on that service to create and edit resource pools.
If you are using a remote service, such as HP Cloud or Rackspace, you must have an account on that cloud provider's system to create and edit resource pools.
If you create a resource pool that requires credentials, the Administration Dashboard validates them when you create a resource pool, instead of when you first use the resource pool.
Click Create Resource Pool.

section.title: How to Edit a Resource Pool
section.p: Use the Edit Resource Pool view to update resource pool definitions that will be used during topology provisioning. In common use cases, you can:

li.p: Change the name of the resource pool.
Switch to a new region.
Update the OpenStack(R) server domain URL.
Modify different provider credentials when the resource is an HP Cloud.
Modify values that were not accurate when you originally entered them.

section.p: Note: If you change your HP Cloud password, you must also change your password in the Edit Resource Pool view.
To update resource pool definitions:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window.
Find the resource pool that you want to edit, and click Edit Resource Pool.
In the Details section, modify the Name, Type, Region ID, Version, Scope, Cloud Profile, and Provider URL.

Depending on the Cloud Type, in the Provider Credentials section, modify the Tenant ID, User Name, and Password. Enter the password again in Confirm Password to validate. If you create a resource pool that requires credentials, the Administration Dashboard validates them when you edit a resource pool, instead of when you first use the resource pool.
Click Update Resource Pool to save your changes.

section.title: How to Add, Edit, or Delete a Resource Pool Service
section.p: Use the Edit Resource Pool Services view to add, edit, and delete services to and from a resource pool.

A service definition uses the model and version properties to identify an infrastructure service that is realized using the specified image/flavor combination. If you find problems in particular model/version, you might be required to add a new resource pool service.
To add a resource pool service:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window. Note: Version must be prefixed by "v". For example, to enter a version 1.0, enter "v1.0".
Click Add Service to open a row of entry boxes for your new service.
Enter the Name, Type, Model, Version, Flavor ID, and select an Image ID (if you have images loaded). Note: Version must be prefixed by "v". For example, to enter a version 1.0, enter "v1.0".
Click Update Resource Pool Services to save your changes.

section.p: To edit a resource pool service:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window.
Find the resource pool you want to edit, and click More > Edit Services.
Keep or modify the service entry boxes.
Click Update Resource Pool Services to save your changes.

section.p: To delete one or more resource pool services:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window.
Select the resource pools you want to delete, and click Delete Services.

section.title: How to Delete a Resource Pool
section.p: Caution: Make sure you really want to delete a resource pool. Deleted resource pools cannot be restored. You must recreate them.
Best Practice: Delete the resource pool after deleting all services that were using that resource pool.
Note: You can delete a resource pool even if a service is provisioned using that resource pool. Also, after the resource pool is deleted, the de-provisioning operation will still succeed.
To delete one or more resource pools:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Provisioning > Resource Pools to open the Resource Pools window.
To delete one resource pool, find the resource pool you want to delete and click More > Delete Resource Pool.
Optional: To delete more than one resource pool, select the resource pools, and click Delete Resource Pools.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Resource Pool.

section.title: Instances
section.p: Instances are all of the VMs running within a selected project.
To view a list of instances:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project from the drop-down list.
Select Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Information shown includes instance name, image name, IP address, size, keypair, status, task, power state, and uptime.
Optional: To see instance details, click an Instance Name to open a window that offers the following tabs:
Overview, where you see instance details and specifications.
Log, which is the system log from the VM. Use this log for debugging and troubleshooting. You can view the full instance log or specify the number of lines of the log file to view.
Console, where you can remotely log directly in to the VM.

section.title: How to Launch an Instance
section.p: Caution: When you set up an instance, carefully make your selections. After the instance is launched, the only editable property is its Name.
To launch an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Click Launch Instance to open the Launch Instance window.
The window opens at the Details tab. Enter the following information:
a. Instance Source: Whether you are launching an image (default) or snapshot.
b. Image: Depending on your selection in the Instance Source field, you are required to select an AMI, RAW, and QCOW2 formatted image or a specific snapshot. (ARI and AKI types cannot be launched.)
c. Availability Zone: Any availability zone or Nova.
d. Instance Name: The name of the host you are creating (Required).
e. Flavor: Indicates the size of the node. When you select a flavor here, the Flavor Details table on the right changes to indicate the node properties and values associated with your size selection.
Name : This is tiny, small, medium, large, or xlarge, or the name of a custom flavor that has been created
CPUs : The number of virtual CPUs.
Root Disk: Assigned by the image.
Ephemeral Disk: A second storage disk available to the VM.
Total Disk: This size is defined in Region > Flavors by the Domain Administrator. It is known as the Root Disk.
RAM: Processor memory.
f. Instance Count: Can be more than 1.
Use the Access and Security tab to control access to your instance via keypairs and security groups.
a. Keypair: Keypairs are ssh credentials that are injected into images when they are launched. The public key is installed on the VM; you will use the private key to log in.
To add a keypair, either:
i. Select a keypair from the list, or
ii. Click (+) to import a keypair. Enter Keypair Name and Public Key.
To create a keypair, see How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair.

b. Security Groups: Security groups are one way to provide a measure of network isolation between different VMs, as they limit the ports into which network traffic can enter the group. You can select multiple groups.
Use the Networking tab to select one or more networks.
You must specify at least one network. You can use the plus (+) symbol or drag-and-drop to select networks. Use the minus (-) sign to remove networks.
Use the Volume Options tab to select boot options for an instance that is launching with attached storage.
Use the Post Creation to customize the instance. This tab is analogous to "User Data" in other systems. The tab allows you to customize the instance by adding a script to run after instance launch.
Click Launch. If the launch is successful, the instance is added to the Instances list with a Power State of Running.

section.title: How to Create an Instance Snapshot
section.p: After you set up, install, and configure an instance, you can create a snapshot to preserve the disk state of the running instance. At a later time, you can use the snapshot to start up another VM.
To create an instance snapshot:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Find the instance you want to snapshot, and click Create Snapshot.
Enter a name for the snapshot.
Click Create Snapshot. The Administration Dashboard displays the snapshot as an image on the Images and Snapshots panel. See Images and Snapshots.

section.title: How to Edit an Instance
section.p: To edit a project instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
In the Instances list, select the Instance you want to edit and then click Edit Instance.
Select the Info tab to update the Name.
In the Security Groups tab, edit security groups, use the plus symbol (+) to add groups and the minus symbol (-) to remove groups:

ul.li: All Security Groups — A list of security groups that are associated with the project, but not the instance.
Instance Security Groups — A list of security groups that are currently associated with the instance.

li.p: Click Save.

section.title: How to Associate a Floating IP to an Instance
section.p: You can associate a Floating IP address to an instance that needs to be visible outside the cloud.
To associate a floating IP to an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Select an instance and then click Associate Floating IP to open the Manage Floating IP Associations window.
Select an IP Address from the list.
Optional: If you do not see available addresses:

ul.li: Click (+) to allocate a floating IP from a pool.
Select a Pool and then click Allocate IP.

li.p: Select a Port to be associated from the list.
Click Associate.

section.title: How to Disassociate a Floating IP from an Instance
section.p: To disassociate a floating IP from an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Find the instance you want to disassociate, and click More > Disassociate Floating IP. A confirmation window opens, warning that the action cannot be undone.
Click Disassociate Floating IP to confirm.

section.title: How to Pause or Resume an Instance
section.p: Pausing an instance stores the content of the VM in memory (RAM). This keeps the instance running, but in a frozen state.
To free up memory and vCPUs, you should suspend an instance.
To pause a project instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Find the instance you want to pause, and click More > Pause Instance.
The Status and Power State of the instance show Paused.

section.p: To resume an instance:

li.p: Select the instance > More > Resume Instance.
After a short time, the Status returns to Active and the Power State returns to Running.

section.title: How to Hard Reboot an Instance
section.p: Rebooting an instance is similar to cycling power on a physical server — the operating system is restarted from scratch. Rebooting temporarily makes the VM and all the services it hosts unavailable. In a common use case, your installation requires a reboot because you installed new software.
To reboot an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Find the instance you want to reboot, and click More > Hard Reboot Instance. A confirmation window opens, warning that the action cannot be undone.
Click Hard Reboot Instance. The Task column indicates the instance is Rebooting Hard. If reboot is successful, the Status shows Active and the Power State shows Running.

section.title: How to Suspend or Resume an Instance
section.p: Suspending an instance frees up memory and vCPUs. Suspension could be compared to hibernation mode.

section.title: Suspend an Instance
section.p: To suspend an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.

Find the instance you want to suspend, and click More > Suspend Instance. The Task column indicates the instance is suspending. When this process completes, the Status shows Suspended, and the Power State shows Shutoff.

section.title: Resume an Instance
section.p: To resume an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.

Find the instance you want to resume, and click More > Resume Instance. The Task column indicates the instance is resuming. When this process completes, the Status returns to Active, and the Power State returns to Running.

section.title: How to Force Delete an Instance
section.p: Use the Force Delete option to delete an instance when it appears to be in an unresponsive state. Any user has the option to Force Delete, which immediately and completely deletes the instance from the project.
To force delete a project instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
In the Instances list, select the instance you want to force delete, and select More > Force Delete. The instance is deleted without a warning prompt.

section.title: How to Terminate an Instance
section.p: When you terminate an instance, the VM is shut down and the resources associated with it are released. It is not possible to start the VM after it is terminated because it no longer exists. Termination is scheduled because it takes some time to free all the resources.
When an instance is terminated:

li.p: Any changes associated with the volume that the image is running on are discarded.
Any changes associated with the volume implied by the disk space (ephemeral) that are specified in the flavor are discarded.
Any changes associated with attached volumes are retained in the attached volume and could be reattached to a different VM.
The VM is removed from any security group it was associated with, and frees its floating IP addresses.

section.p: To terminate one or more instances:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Instances to open the Instances window.
Select one or more instances to terminate, and click More > Terminate Instance.
In the Confirm Terminate Instance dialog, verify your selection and then click Terminate Instance(s).
Wait for the success message.
