section.title: Volumes
section.p: Volumes are the disk storage volumes that have been created in the project. Volumes are persistent — you can create data in these volumes and attach them to various VMs (instances) over time, as needed.
To see a list of volumes:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Volumes to open the Volumes window.

p.xref: How to Create a Volume from an Image or Instance Snapshot
How to Attach or Detach Volumes to an Instance
How to Create a Volume Snapshot

section.title: How to Create a Volume
section.p: After you create a volume, you can attach it to a VM and place content in it.
To create a volume:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
a. To create a volume that is not based on an image, enter:

ul.li: Volume Name: A volume name is required.
Description: Optional description.
Type: Choose a volume type. Volume types are defined by cloud administrators, at the region level.
Size: In GB.
Volume Source: Leave the default, not based on a snapshot or image.

li.p: b. To create a volume that is based on an image or snapshot:

ul.li: Volume Source
Select Snapshot to display the Use snapshot as a source menu. If the dashboard does not contain snapshots, you do not see this option.
Select Image to display the Use image as a source menu.
Select an image or snapshot from the source menu. Keep or modify the entries that are automatically populated from the source.

li.p: Click Create Volume. The volume is created and available to attach to VMs.

section.title: How to Create a Volume from an Image or Instance Snapshot
section.p: To create a volume from an image or instance snapshot:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots to open the Images and Snapshots window.
Find the image or snapshot that you want to use, and click More > Create Volume to open a dialog box where you enter:

ul.li: Volume Name: A default name is based on the image name.
Description: Optional description.
Type: Defined by cloud administrators, at the region level.
Size: In GB.
Use image as source: Populated by the image name.

li.p: Click Create Volume.

section.title: How to Attach or Detach Volumes to an Instance
section.p: Volumes are disk storage volumes that have been created in a project and can be attached to an instance. A volume can only be attached to a single VM at a time, and that VM has sole use of that volume.
To attach a project volume to an instance:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
Find the volume you want to attach, and click Edit Attachments to open the Manage Volume Attachments dialog box.
Select an instance from Attach to Instance.
Enter a Device Name, which is an attached device, such as a device between /dev/vdc and /dev/vdz.
Click Attach Volume.

section.p: To detach a volume from an instance:

ul.li: After a volume is attached, Detach Volume is available through the Attach Volume action.

section.title: How to Create a Volume Snapshot
section.p: To create a project volume snapshot:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
Find the volume you want to snapshot, and click More > Create Snapshot.
Enter a Name for the snapshot and a Description.
Click Create Snapshot. The volume snapshot is added to Images and Snapshots.

section.title: How to Delete a Volume
section.p: Deleting a volume means the volume will no longer exist, the data will be lost, it cannot be attached to any VM, and no user can access it.
Caution: Deleting a volume cannot be undone.
To delete one or more project volumes:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Volumes to open the Volumes window.
To delete one volume, find the volume and select More > Delete Volume.
Optional: To delete multiple volumes, select the checkboxes for the volumes you want to delete, and click Delete Volume.
In the warning dialog box, verify your selection, and click Delete Volume.

section.title: Images and Snapshots
section.p: When you launch a VM, the launch is based on an image. This Images view lists only the launchable images that can be used to create new VMs:

row.entry: AMI (Amazon Machine Image) — Not valid unless it is associated with a kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI).

section.p: To see a list of project images:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots to open the Images and Snapshots window.
Information shown includes image name, type, status, format, whether the image is public, and whether the image is protected.
Optional: To see image details, click the Image Name to open the Image Overview window.

p.xref: How to Edit an Image or Instance Snapshot
How to Launch an Image or Instance Snapshot
How to Delete an Image or Instance Snapshot
How to Delete a Volume Snapshot

section.title: How to Create an Image
section.p: You can create and configure an image to upload to the Image Service. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.
To create an image:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots > Create Image.
On the Create an Image dialog box, enter a Name and optional Description.
Enter one of the following for the Image Source:

ul.li: Image File: Then browse to select the file.
Image Location: Then enter the image URL. It must be a valid and direct HTTP URL to the image binary. URLs that redirect or serve error pages will result in unusable images.

li.p: Note: If you do not have rights to the image's URL, you receive an error when trying to create the image.
The image must be accessible to the Image Service and in a supported format.
Note: If you upload an image with a format that is not supported, you will receive an Error 404, Not Found error when you attempt to create the image.
Select a Format. The image must be in one of the formats listed.
Enter the Minimum Disk space and Minimum Ram.
Leave Public unselected to create a private image.
To learn whether you have permission to create a public image, see your role tasks under Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
Leave Protected unselected to create an image that other users can edit or delete.

Select Protected to create a read-only image that other users cannot edit or delete. To learn whether you have permission to create a protected image, see your role under Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.

Click Create Image. If successful, the image displays with an Active status. If creation is not successful within a specified amount of time (set by your system administrator; typically no more than five minutes), the Status of the image in the list displays Upload Failed.

section.p: Note: Only AMI, RAW, and QCOW2 images are launchable.

section.title: How to Edit an Image or Instance Snapshot
section.p: You cannot modify an image format.

When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.
To edit an image or instance snapshot:

li.p: Click Project > Images and Snapshots to open the Images and Snapshots window.
Find the image or snapshot you want to edit, and click More > Edit.
Keep or edit:

ul.li: Name: As desired.
Description: Optional description.
Public: Visibility.
Protected: Select to mark the image as read-only. A protected image cannot be edited or deleted.

li.p: Click Update Image.

section.title: How to Launch an Image or Instance Snapshot
section.p: You can only launch images that are formatted as AMI, RAW, and QCOW2. Launching an image provisions it to the cloud.
To launch an image:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots to open the Images window.
Find the image to launch, and click Launch to open the Launch Instance dialog box. The dialog opens to the Details tab. Some fields are automatically populated from the image.
Enter or edit the Details tab information as needed:

ul.li: Instance Source: Specify whether you are using an image or snapshot.
Image or Instance Snapshot: Select from the list of images that have been uploaded to the system.
Availability Zone: Any availability zone or Nova.
Instance Name: The name of the host you are creating (Required).
Flavor: Indicates the size of the node. When you select a flavor here, the Flavor Details table on the right changes to show the node properties and values associated with your size selection.
Instance Count: Can be more than 1.

li.p: Use the Access and Security tab to control access to your instance via pairs and security groups.
a. Keypair: Keypairs are ssh credentials that are injected into images when they are launched. The public key is installed on the VM; you will use the private key to log in.
To add a keypair, either:

ul.li: Select a keypair from the list, or
Click (+) to import a keypair. Enter Keypair Name and Public Key.

li.p: To create a keypair, see How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair.
b. Enter Admin Password and Confirm Admin Password.
c. Select a Security Group.
Use the Networking tab to select one or more networks (required).
You must specify at least one network. You can click the plus (+) symbol or drag and drop to make your selections. Use the minus (-) symbol to remove networks.
Use the Volume Options tab to select boot options for an instance that launches with attached storage.
Use the Post Creation tab to customize the instance by adding a script to run after launch. The Customization Script field is analogous to "User Data" in other systems.
Click Launch. If successful, the image is added to the Images list with an Active status.

section.title: How to Delete an Image or Instance Snapshot
section.p: Images are protected from deletion by rules. If you are not allowed to delete an image, you receive an error when you attempt to delete the image.
If you delete an image that is used in a design or profile, an attempt to provision the document will fail.
To delete one or more images:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots.
Find the image you want to delete, and click More > Delete Image.
Optional: To delete multiple images, select the images and click Delete Images.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box. Click Delete Image.

section.title: How to Delete a Volume Snapshot
section.p: To delete one or more volume snapshots:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots to open the Images and Snapshots window.
Find the volume snapshot you want to delete, and click More > Delete Volume Snapshot.
Optional: To delete multiple volume snapshots, select the snapshots and click Delete Volume Snapshots.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Volume Snapshot.

section.title: Networks
section.p: From this view, you can create, edit, and delete project networks. You can also add subnets using this view.

p.xref: How to Create a Private Network

section.title: How to Create a Private Network
section.p: You can create a private network that is assigned to your current project.
Note: You cannot create an external network on the Project tab. You must have access to the Region tab to create a shared or external network. See How to Create an External Network.
To create a private network:

ol.li: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.
Click Create Network to open the Create Network dialog box.

On the Network tab of the dialog box:
Enter a Network Name for your network.
Make sure Admin State is checked. This is the administrative state of the network. If you select Admin State, the network forwards packets. If you do not select Admin State, the network does not forward packets.

On the Subnet tab of the dialog box:
To create a network with no associated subnet, unselect Create Subnet and click Create.
If you want to create a network with an associated subnet, keep Create Subnet selected and continue through the following steps:
Enter a Subnet Name.
Enter Network Address.
Select an IP Version.
Optional: Enter a Gateway IP. This is the IP address that servers on the subnet will use if the address they want to send to is not on the subnet. It is a gateway to other networks. In a common use case, the gateway address would be that of a router; however, it could also be of another server that is providing routing services.
Select Disable Gateway to make the subnet private. Packets cannot leave the subnet, except through other devices on the network.

On the Subnet Detail tab of the dialog box:
Leave Enable DHCP selected to dynamically allocate IP addresses. This is the appropriate selection for a private network.
Enter an Allocation Pools IP address list for the subnet, using one line in the entry box for each address.
Enter a DNS Name Servers IP address list for the subnet, using one line in the entry box for each address.
Enter a Host Routes IP address list to announce additional routes to the hosts. Use one line in the entry box for each address.
Click Create.
Verify that the network you just created is included in the Networks list.

section.title: How to Edit a Network
section.p: You can edit a network that is assigned to a project. In a common use case, you need to edit when the Admin State should be changed, such as for maintenance or testing efforts.
To edit a network:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.
Find the network you want to edit, and click Edit Network to open the Edit Network window.
Change the Name or Admin State. You cannot edit the ID.
Click Save Changes.
Wait for the success message.

section.title: How to Create a Subnet
section.p: You can create a subnet on a network. Subnets allow you to divide a network into addressable segments.
Note: You must be the Admin user or a cloud administrator to create a subnet on an external network or shared network.
To create a subnet:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.

Find the network where you want to add a subnet, and click
More > Add Subnet
to open the Create Subnet dialog box.
Note: An alternate method is to click Create Subnet on the Networks Overview window. The Create Subnet dialog box opens.
On the Subnet tab of the dialog box:
a. Enter a unique Subnet Name.
b. Enter a Network Address from your assigned, dedicated IP address range.
c. Keep the defaults for IP Version, Gateway IP, and Disable Gateway.
On the Subnet Detail tab of the dialog box:
a. Leave Enable DHCP.
b. Enter an Allocation Pools IP address list for the subnet, using one line in the entry box for each address.
c. Enter a DNS Name Servers IP address list for the subnet, using one line in the entry box for each address.
d. Enter a Host Routes IP address list to announce additional routes to the hosts. Use one line in the entry box for each address.
The Networks window opens, and you see the subnet.

section.title: How to Edit a Subnet
section.p: In many cases, subnet details change after it is created. As a result of these changes, you might need to update information. For example:

li.p: If you entered an incorrect subnet gateway address during subnet creation, or if the subnet gateway address changes, you can correct the subnet gateway address. You cannot change the mask of a subnet.
You can change or add DNS servers, and modify routing information.

section.p: To edit a subnet:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.
Click the Network Name where you want to edit a subnet. The Network Overview window opens.
Find the subnet you want to edit, and click Edit Subnet to open the Update Subnet dialog box where:

ul.li: On the Subnet tab of the dialog box, you can change the Subnet Name, Gateway IP, or Disable Gateway settings. You cannot edit the Network Address.
On the Subnet Details tab of the dialog box, you can change the Enable DHCP setting, DNS Name Servers, or Host Routes settings.

li.p: Click Update.
The Network Overview window opens, and you see the edits.

section.title: How to Delete a Subnet
section.p: To delete a subnet:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.
Find the network where you want to delete a subnet, and click the Name to open the Network Overview window.
Find the subnet you want to delete, and click More > Delete Subnet.
Optional: To delete multiple subnets, select the subnets, and click Delete Subnet.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Subnet.

section.title: How to Delete a Network
section.p: You can delete a network that is assigned to a project. In a common use case, you want to delete a network that you decide is no longer required in the project.
To delete a one or more networks:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Networks to open the Networks window.
Find the network you want to delete, and click More > Delete Network.
Optional: To delete multiple networks, select the networks, and click Delete Networks.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Network.

section.title: Routers
section.p: A router is a logical entity for forwarding packets across internal subnets and NATting them on external networks through an appropriate external gateway.

A router has an interface for each subnet it is associated with. By default, the IP address of this interface is the subnet's gateway IP. When a router is associated with a subnet, a port for that router interface will be added to the subnet's network.
To see a list of routers:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Routers to open the Routers window.
In the Routers list, click on the name of the router to open the Router Overview window.
Verify general information about the selected router and Interfaces, such as the External Network for your public network.

p.xref: How to Add an Internal Interface to a Router
How to Add an External Interface to a Router

section.title: How to Create a Router
section.p: You can create a router to interconnect subnets and forward traffic within the subnets.

A router has an interface for each subnet it is associated with. By default, the IP address of this interface is the subnet's gateway IP. When a router is associated with a subnet, a port for that router interface will be added to the subnet's network.
To create a router:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Routers to open the Routers window.
Click Create Router.
On the Create Router dialog, enter a Router Name.
Click Create Router.

section.title: How to Add an Internal Interface to a Router
section.p: To learn whether you have permission, see your role under Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To add an internal interface to a project router:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Routers to open the Routers window.
Click the name of a router where you want to add an interface to open an Overview window.
Click Add Interface.
In the Add Interface window:

ul.li: Select a subnet from the drop-down list.
Leave the IP Address field blank.

li.p: Click Add Interface.
Wait for the success message.
Go back to the Router Overview to verify the Interfaces information:

ul.li: External and Internal interfaces are identified.
The initial Internal Interface Status is DOWN.
After an Instance is created using this router, the Status will change to ACTIVE.

section.title: How to Add an External Interface to a Router
section.p: To learn whether you have permission, see your role under Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
To add an external interface to a router:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Routers to open the Routers window.
Click the router Name to open an Overview window.
Click Add Gateway Interface.
In the Set Gateway window, select an External Network from the drop-down list.
Click Set Gateway.

section.title: How to Delete a Router
section.p: To delete one or more project routers:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Routers to open the Routers window.
Find the router you want to delete, and click More > Delete Router.
Optional: To delete multiple routers, select routers and click Delete Routers.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Router.
The Routers window opens, and you do not see the routers listed.

section.title: How to See a Network Topology Diagram
section.p: You can see a layout diagram of project networks, subnets, and routers.
To see the diagram:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Infrastructure > Network Topology. You can launch instances, and create networks and routers on this window. Follow the steps described in the instances, networks, and routers topics below.

p.xref: How to Create a Private Network

section.title: Security Groups and Rules
section.p: Security groups are one way to provide a measure of network isolation between different VMs because they limit the ports into which network traffic can enter the group. Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.

p.xref: How to Create or Delete a Security Group
How to Add or Delete a Security Group Rule

section.title: How to Create or Delete a Security Group
section.p: Security groups are one way to provide a measure of network isolation between different VMs because they limit the ports into which network traffic can enter the group. Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.
To create a security group:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Security Groups tab.
Click Create Security Group.
On the Create Security Group dialog, enter a Name and Description.
Click Create Security Group.
Wait for the success message.
Verify that the new security group is included in the Security Groups list.

section.p: To delete one or more security groups:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Security Groups tab.
Find the security group that you want to delete, and click More > Delete Security Group.
Optional: To delete multiple security groups, select the security groups and click Delete Security Groups.
Confirm your selection in the warning dialog box, and click Delete Security Groups.

section.p: Note: You cannot delete the default Security Group.

section.title: How to Add or Delete a Security Group Rule
section.p: Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.
To create a security group rules:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Security Groups tab.
Select the group to edit, and click Edit Rules.
In the Security Group Rules view, click Add Rule.
In the Add Rule window, enter the following information:
a. Rule: Select from the drop-down list.
b. Direction: Select Ingress or Egress.
c. Open Port:
Select Port to open a single port. Then enter Port.

Select Port Range if you want to enter a starting and ending port. Then enter From Port (the source port, such as 80) and To Port (the port where VMs inside the security group receive traffic, such as 80).
Remote: Specify the source of traffic this rule allows. Select one of the following.
CIDR: To specify a range (a block) of IP addresses. The block defines how many addresses to create. Then enter CIDR.
Security Group: The source group will allow any other instance in this security group access to any other instance. Then select a Security Group and Ether Type.
Click Add.
Verify that the new rule is included in the Security Group Rules list.

section.p: To delete security group rules:

li.p: In the Security Group Rules list, find the rule you want to delete, and click Delete Rule.
In the Confirm Delete Rule dialog, verify the name of the rule, and then click Delete Rule.
Verify that the new rule is excluded from in the Security Group Rules list.

section.title: How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair
section.p: If you need a keypair, you must create or import the keypair for yourself. No other user can create or import a keypair for you.

Keypairs are ssh security keys (credentials) that are 512 bits long. A keypair consists of a public key and a private key. The credentials provide authentication and allow you to exchange traffic securely within a VM.
If you want a secure, provisioned cloud instance, you must use a keypair to launch images or topologies:

li.p: The public key portion is installed on the VM.
Users use the private key portion to ssh to the launched instance.

section.p: You can use the Administration Dashboard to create a keypair, or to import a keypair you previously created.

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Keypairs tab.
On the Keypairs tab, click Create Keypair.
Enter a Keypair Name — free-form text that does not include spaces, for example: testonlykeypair.
Click Create Keypair.
The private key portion is downloaded to your browser system as a .pem file. You can only download the file once. It is important to save the file in a safe location.
The Administration Dashboard maintains the public key portion within the cloud and injects it into launched instances.

section.title: To import a keypair
section.p: You might have previously created a keypair that you want to use. To import a keypair:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Keypairs tab.
Click Import Keypair.
On the Import Keypair dialog, enter:
Keypair Name: Free form text that does not include spaces, for example testonlykeypair.
Public Key: The public key portion.
Click Import Keypair.
On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Keypairs tab.
Select one or more keypairs.
Click Delete Keypair.

section.title: Floating IPs
section.p: You can allocate additional floating IP addresses to a project. This process does not assign the address to a particular instance in the project.
After you allocate an IP to your project, you can associate or disassociate the address to an instance.
You can release a floating IP address that is associated with your project. When you release the floating IP, it becomes available to other projects.

p.xref: How to Allocate a Floating IP
How to Associate or Disassociate Floating IPs
How to Release a Floating IP

section.title: How to Allocate a Floating IP
section.p: To allocate a floating IP to a project:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Floating IPs tab.
In the Floating IPs list, click Allocate IP To Project.
In the Allocate Floating IP dialog, select a Pool from the drop-down list.
Click Allocate IP.

section.title: How to Associate or Disassociate Floating IPs
section.p: You can assign an address to a particular VM instance.
To associate a floating IP:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Floating IPs tab.
In the Floating IPs list, select an IP address and click Allocate IP to Project.
In the Allocate Floating IP dialog, select a Pool from the drop-down list.
Click Allocate IP.
Wait for the success message.

section.p: To disassociate a floating IP:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Floating IPs tab.
In the Floating IPs list, select an address where the Disassociate Floating IP action is available.
Click Disassociate Floating IP.
Wait for the success message.

section.title: How to Release a Floating IP
section.p: To release a floating IP:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Floating IPs tab.
Find the IP that you want to release, and click More > Release Floating IP.
Wait for the success message.

section.title: How to Access API Endpoints
section.p: To access API endpoints:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > API Access tab.
Information shown includes service name and service endpoint.

section.title: How to Access Your Authentication Token
section.p: The Administration Dashboard manages your authentication token. The Administration Dashboard retrieves your token from the Keystone service when you successfully log in to the dashboard.

You can access your authentication token in the Administration Dashboard for subsequent use outside the dashboard. For example, when you use a REST client to request an OpenStack(R) service, you might need to supply your authentication token.
To access your authentication token:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Access and Security > Access and Security > Authentication Token tab.
A truncated version of the token displays. Click More to see the entire token.

section.title: Updates and Extensions
section.p: The Updates and Extensions window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to access the HP Helion Distribution Network (HDN). Use the Updates and Extensions window to access catalog updates and content. Updates include software versions and security patches. Content includes material such as images and topology templates.
You can update and upgrade the Administration Dashboard while your system continues to run. HDN contains all the products and services HP offers to help maintain your cloud.
To learn whether you have permission to use HDN, see Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role.
You must configure the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard to access an HP Cloud OS Distribution Network account before you can use the Updates and Extensions window. See the Tasks sections, below.
The Updates and Extensions window provides the standard Administration Dashboard filter capability, and you can click on the column headings to sort by that item.
To see updates:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Updates and Extensions > Updates and Extensions to open the Updates and Extensions window.
You see information about the available updates and extensions:
Name: of the update.
Version: of the update. Information for each version is listed on a separate line.
Size: of the update.
Provider: which organization created and is responsible for the update.
Type: the kind of image that downloads.

Status: the state of the update in the catalog. This state is independent of your local system. For example, you may successfully download an update, but the update later becomes suspended in the catalog. You can continue to publish and use the update on your local system.
Actions: tasks you can perform on the update.

section.p: To see details of an update:

li.p: Click a Name to open an Overview window.
Information includes the update name, version, targets where it is installed, and manifest. (In future releases, the manifest will define the contents of the file.)

section.title: How to Configure an Updates and Extensions Account
section.p: If you want to use HDN, you must configure the Administration Dashboard to access it. If you do not have access, the Administration Dashboard displays a warning when you open the Updates and Extensions window.
To configure:

li.p: Create a HDN account.
Configure the Administration Dashboard to access that account.

section.p: To create an account:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Updates and Extensions > Updates and Extensions to open the Updates and Extensions window. You see a warning that your credentials are not configured to access the catalog.
Click Configure to open the Configure window.

ul.li: If you already have a HDN account, you can skip to Step 5.
If you need to create an HP catalog account, continue.

li.p: Click Sign up now to open the HDN Create Account window, where you:

ul.li: Enter your Name, Email, and Password.
Agree to the terms.
Click Submit. You can close the HDN window.

li.p: On the Administration Dashboard Configure window:

ul.li: Enter your HDN account email address for your User Name.
Enter your HDN account password for your Password.
Click OK.

li.p: If you configure successfully, you can use the Updates and Extensions window.

section.title: About Account Cookies
section.p: When you configure an account, the Administration Dashboard stores a cookie on your computer. The Administration Dashboard uses the cookie the next time you access the Updates and Extensions window, so you need to enter username and password information only one time.
If your browser blocks cookies, you cannot configure an account.

If you clear cookies on your computer, you must configure your account again. You do not have access to HDN until you configure. However, if you downloaded updates and they exist in your cache, you still see them on your Updates and Extensions window.

section.title: How to Download an Update or Extension
section.p: Download an update to copy it from the catalog to your local system where you can use it. If an update is not available for download, you do not see Download. For example, you cannot download an update that was previously downloaded and still exists in cache.
To download an update:

li.p: Click Updates and Extensions > Updates and Extensions to open the Updates and Extensions window.
Find the update or extension that you want to download, and click Download to open the Download confirmation box.
Confirm the download name and version, and click Download.

The download is scheduled and runs in background. The Administration Dashboard allows 24 hours for a download to complete. If the download runs for more than 24 hours, the download terminates with an error message. You can reschedule the download for a time when fewer jobs are running, so it executes more quickly.
Optional: You can check the download progress action to understand the details of the download status.

section.p: Note: Downloads require large amounts of disk space. Successful downloads require that your local system contains adequate disk space. For information about what to do when you run out of space or experience other download problems, see the Troubleshooting topic.

section.title: How to Publish an Update or Extension
section.p: You can publish an update after you download it. If you have not yet downloaded the update, you do not see Publish.
A download can consist of one or more pieces that must be distributed to multiple HP Cloud OS repositories. Publish routes the download contents to their appropriate repositories.
To publish an update:

li.p: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.
Click Updates and Extensions > Updates and Extensions to open the Updates and Extensions window.
Click Publish to open the Targets dialog box.

ul.li: Enter Scope to define who can use the update. The Administration Dashboard offers scope choices, depending upon the update type.
Click Publish.

li.p: After a successful publish, you see the update in the appropriate section of the Administration Dashboard. For example, if the update is a Glance image, you can see it on Infrastructure > Images and Snapshots.

section.title: Administration Dashboard Settings
section.p: All users see the Settings link on every Administration Dashboard window. The link allows you to change your personal settings and access online help.

section.title: How to Change User Settings
section.p: To change Administration Dashboard display settings:

li.p: Click Settings in the upper right of any window.
Click User.
In the User Settings window, keep or change the following settings:

ul.li: Language: English (en).
Timezone: UTC (Coordinated Universal Time). To change the default, select a timezone from the drop-down list.
Items Per Page: This number represents how many line items display on one page. To change the default, enter a different number.
Click Save.

li.p: Wait for the success message.

section.title: How to Change Your Password
section.p: To change your Administration Dashboard password:

li.p: Click Settings in the upper right of any window.
Click Password.
In the Change Password window:

ul.li: Current password: Enter your current password.
New password: Enter the word that you want for your new password.
Confirm new password: Enter your new password again to confirm your entry.
Click Change.

section.title: About the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard
section.p: To view version information about the Administration Dashboard:

li.p: Click Settings in the upper right of any window.
Click About.
In the About window, review the Dashboard Version, Build Version, and Copyrights information.
